messages.author: smolinari

messages.content: Hey everyone, I just thought I'd share my current setup and see if anyone has any thoughts/recommendations on best practices. I feel there's probably a better way but I just can't think of it as of now. My current setup is that I have a single vm (which has a couple of other containers on it) that uses docker for external services. I'm using traefik hosted on the same system and their docker labels to expose it coder for my domain. I currently have traefik_proxy and coder_backend docker.  In order for to have coder properly communicate with itself, I had to set an alias on the traefik_proxy network for the traefik container itself for the domain of my coder instance which allowed all health checks to complete correct. This made everything work except for the workspace connections themselves. By default, workspaces are added to the default docker network and as a result were not able to access the access url and download the coder agent. To fix this, I had to adjust the docker container terraform template to use the traefik_proxy network so that it has the correct routing for the access url. Now this works fine as of now but ideally to create some separation between the workspaces and the other containers on the vm itself, I'd like to create a separate docker network that the only the coder container and workspaces have access to for better separation between other services. Does anyone have any recommendations for this setup? If anyone wants to see my compose files/terraform configs or wants some clarification, let me know. I wanted to try and not make this too big of a post (even though it's already an essay).

messages.content:
Hey folks, I think https://github.com/coder/registry/pull/485 and related PRs broke the claude code module compatibility with Tasks, based upon how this should work according to the docs (https://coder.com/docs/@v2.28.3/ai-coder/tasks#option-2-create-or-duplicate-your-own-template). This PR removed the `coder_ai_task` resource from the agentapi module, and it was not added back to claude code module, so now users of  the claude code module need to add this themselves. The docs explicitly say that this shouldn't be necessary.

Might be worth updating the docs and/or the modules to address this. I'm a new coder user and this issue made for a less than ideal eval of the tool, and is probably affecting other people trying to eval coder as well.

messages.author: phorcys

messages.content:
Hi, I‚Äôm a DevOps engineer working for a small business.
After using Coder.com for a month (with the enterprise license trial), I‚Äôd like to share some feedback.

## Why I Chose Coder
My team is small, with only a few permanent members, while most contributors come and go. I opted for devcontainers or cloud development primarily to reduce costs and onboarding time for these temporary contributors.

I prioritized Coder because it offers a self-hosted and self-managed solution.

TL;DR: A self-hosted and self-managed solution that enables one-click-ready-to-dev setups.

## First Impressions
The first thing that caught my attention was the documentation, which seemed detailed and comprehensive. It was easy to set up using Helm (my preferred method), and the interface was designed to be user-friendly‚Äîeven for the most monkey users.

However, the documentation wasn‚Äôt as complete as it appeared. There‚Äôs a relationship between the Coder repo and the Envbuilder repo, but Envbuilder is rarely mentioned in the docs. To get things working, I had to piece together information from the Coder docs and the `readme.md` of Envbuilder.

## Features Overview
The features of Coder are what inspired me to write this feedback.

First, support terraform  in templates. If you‚Äôre familiar with Terraform, you literally can practically do anything with it. Second, greate flexibility. Coder provides two powerful resources: `coder_app` and `coder_script`. `coder_script `allows you to execute scripts. `coder_app` enables open access to ports when necessary.

The GitHub repo `coder/modules` contains Terraform modules to help you enhance your templates. However, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend using them directly due to their instability. Instead, I suggest customizing the `coder_app` and `coder_script` resources based on these modules before applying them to your templates.

Additionally, Coder offers permission hierarchies for templates and workspaces, though they didn‚Äôt significantly affect my experience.

## My Experience
It took me a week to set up a cloud development environment to achieve a one-click ready-to-dev experience for new users.

After discovering the power of Terraform, I set up additional one-click options for creating JupyterLab, etc, ...nearly anything else I needed.

## Comparison with Similar Platforms
### Lapdev
Lapdev builds from devcontainer.json remarkably fast and doesn‚Äôt seem to have the limitations I faced with Envbuilder. However, it doesn‚Äôt yet support Kubernetes self-hosted setups (strangely), so I reluctantly ruled it out.

### GitHub Codespaces
Coder clearly aims to be an alternative to Codespaces, so there‚Äôs not much to elaborate here.

### Gitpod
Gitpod stopped supporting self-hosted environments around late October 2024. While that‚Äôs a loss for the self-hosted community, it aligns with Gitpod‚Äôs focus on other areas.

### JetBrains Space
Doesn‚Äôt allow self-managed setups.


## Conclusion
Coder provides a solution that meets the requirements I was looking for: self-hosted, self-managed, highly flexible, and easy to use for new users.

However, its build times are incredibly slow‚Äîso slow that the existence of Lapdev only highlights this shortcoming further.

messages.content:
Good to know about the Docker update in 25.10, that actually simplifies things!

If you switch to the LinuxServer.io code-server image, it supports custom startup scripts right out of the box. You don‚Äôt need an external script or to rebuild the image, just drop a file in the right folder and it‚Äôll run automatically on container start.

Setup Steps
1. Find your config volume path‚Ä®In the TrueNAS Apps UI, check where /config is mounted on your host.‚Ä®It should look something like:
/mnt/pool/apps/code-server/config

2. Create the startup script on the host (inside the config volume):
mkdir -p /mnt/pool/apps/code-server/config/custom-cont-init.d
nano /mnt/pool/apps/code-server/config/custom-cont-init.d/install-python.sh

3. Add this content to the script:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Installing Python..."
apt-get update
apt-get install -y python3 python3-pip python3-venv
echo "Python installation complete!"

4. Make it executable:
chmod +x /mnt/pool/apps/code-server/config/custom-cont-init.d/install-python.sh

5. Restart the container
The LinuxServer.io image will automatically run any scripts in that custom-cont-init.d folder on startup. 

Optional: After restarting, check the container logs for:
Python installation complete!

üìò Docs: https://docs.linuxserver.io/general/container-customization/#custom-scripts

messages.content:
Make sure it's executable (chmod +x). This only works if your code-server app is based on the LinuxServer.io image.

2. Install Python to a persistent path
Use pyenv or compile Python to a location inside /config (e.g., /config/.local/). Add to your .bashrc in /config:

export PATH="/config/.local/bin:$PATH"

This survives reboots without needing to reinstall.

3. DOCKER_MODS (limited applicability)
If your app is LinuxServer.io-based AND the TrueNAS app UI lets you add custom environment variables:

DOCKER_MODS=linuxserver/mods:universal-package-install
INSTALL_PACKAGES=python3|python3-pip
Many TrueNAS catalog apps don't expose this option without editing the Helm chart (advanced).

4. Consider Jailmaker (recommended alternative)
https://github.com/Jip-Hop/jailmaker creates persistent Debian jails on TrueNAS SCALE where all installations survive reboots. This avoids fighting the Kubernetes abstraction layer entirely and gives you a normal Linux environment.

Bottom line
Option 1 (if LinuxServer.io image) or Option 4 (Jailmaker) are probably your best bets. The TrueNAS Apps system abstracts away a lot of container configuration, which can make customizations like this frustrating.

messages.content:
Yeah, that's exactly the issue - the container filesystem is ephemeral and only mounted volumes (like /config) persist.

When you install Python via apt or similar inside the code-server container, it installs to the container's root filesystem, which gets reset on every reboot. TrueNAS only persists data in explicitly mounted volumes.

TrueNAS SCALE Apps use Kubernetes (Helm charts), not plain Docker. This means Docker-specific workarounds you might find online don't always apply, and the UI may not expose all the configuration options you need.

Workarounds
1. Startup script in persistent storage (if using LinuxServer.io image)
LinuxServer.io containers look for scripts in /config/custom-cont-init.d/ and run them on startup. Create a script there:

messages.content:
**The `count` meta-argument is a Terraform feature, not Coder-specific.** It's not in the `coder_script` docs because it's a [built-in Terraform meta-argument](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/meta-arguments/count) available on all resources.

**Why it's needed:**

Look at line 165 in the aws-linux template:
```hcl
resource "coder_agent" "dev" {
  count = data.coder_workspace.me.start_count
  ...
}
```

The agent itself uses `count = data.coder_workspace.me.start_count`. This means:
- When workspace is **starting**: `start_count = 1` ‚Üí creates 1 agent ‚Üí `coder_agent.dev` is a list with 1 element
- When workspace is **stopping**: `start_count = 0` ‚Üí creates 0 agents ‚Üí `coder_agent.dev` is an **empty list**

**Your error occurred because:**

When the workspace stops, Terraform runs again. At that point `coder_agent.dev[0]` doesn't exist (empty tuple), so your `coder_script` referencing `coder_agent.dev[0].id` fails.

**The fix:**

Adding `count = data.coder_workspace.me.start_count` to your `coder_script` makes it conditional too:
- Workspace starting ‚Üí agent exists, script exists, reference works
- Workspace stopping ‚Üí agent doesn't exist, script doesn't exist, no reference error

This is the standard pattern in Coder templates - any resource that depends on the agent needs the same `count` to stay in sync.

messages.content:
I took the aws-linux template and added this startup script

```

  agent_id     = coder_agent.dev[0].id
  display_name = "Health check"
  icon         = "/icon/heart.svg"
  cron         = "0 */5 * * * *" # Run every 5 minutes
  script       = <<EOF

    echo "Health check at $(date)"
  EOF
  run_on_start = true
}
```

This got me:
```
Error: Invalid index on main.tf line 136, in resource "coder_script" "every_5_minutes": 136: agent_id = coder_agent.dev[0].id ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ ‚îÇ coder_agent.dev is empty tuple The given key does not identify an element in this collection value: the collection has no elements.
```

So then I added in `count = data.coder_workspace.me.start_count` to the script, and that seemed to work. I'm confused as to what count even does though, as it's not in the documentation for `coder_script` anywhere (https://registry.terraform.io/providers/coder/coder/latest/docs/resources/script). 

Could I get get some pointers on where to find information on why `data.coder_workspace.me.start_count` is needed and what it actually does in the context of `coder_scripts`? My understanding is that it's 0 when the EC2 instance is terminating and 1 when it's starting (https://registry.terraform.io/providers/coder/coder/latest/docs/data-sources/workspace#start_count-1).

messages.author: ethanndickson
messages.threadName: What Ollama models are good to use with Mux for editing files?

messages.content:
I run Ollama on an NVIDIA DGX Spark workstation for local inferencing with port forwarding, and the IBM Granite 4 and Qwen3 Coder models work well for file editing when configured with my Zen editor, but when I try the same with Mux I'm able to get normal model responses but with seemingly no ability to edit files. The AI in the Mux documentation site says:

```
mux does support file editing through tools like file_edit_replace_string, file_edit_insert, file_read, and bash. However, tool calling capability depends on the model itself, not just mux.

The issue with your local Ollama models (IBM Granite4, Qwen3-coder) is likely that these models may not reliably support the tool/function calling format that mux uses. mux is built on the Vercel AI SDK and provides tools to models, but the model must properly understand and invoke those tools.

The limitation: Not all local models handle tool calling well. mux's documentation notes that "different models react very differently to the same set of tools and instructions." Some smaller or less capable models may struggle with structured tool use.

You might try models known for better tool calling support, or check if your Ollama models have specific tool-calling variants.
```

Since I know this works in Zed, are there other suggested models to try? Trying to shortcut the list since there are so many models and it takes time to download them all to the Spark. Thanks.

Greeting, everyone!

I‚Äôm an AI + Full Stack Engineer focused on building production-grade AI systems for healthcare, covering clinical NLP, lab/blood work workflows, medical imaging, and patient-facing AI applications.
I also build LLM systems, autonomous agents, workflow automation, and multimodal AI (text ¬∑ voice ¬∑ vision).

Core Skills :
‚Ä¢ Healthcare AI pipelines: document/PDF extraction + OCR, normalization, reference-range flagging, longitudinal trend analysis
‚Ä¢ Clinical NLP: NER + linking, terminology mapping (SNOMED-CT/UMLS, LOINC-ready workflows), structured signal extraction from notes
‚Ä¢ Medical imaging AI: preprocessing transforms, training/inference pipelines, evaluation workflows, generative imaging experiments
‚Ä¢ LLM systems for healthcare: orchestration (ReAct-style tool use), safety guardrails, grounded generation, traceable reasoning and outputs
‚Ä¢ Agentic AI systems: multi-agent workflows, tool calling, memory, human-in-the-loop review, production chatbots/copilots
‚Ä¢ RAG + knowledge systems: vector DBs, hybrid search, clinical knowledge bases/biomarker catalogs, custom retrievers
